verses.text: My son, if thou be surety for thy friend, \add If\add* thou hast stricken thy hand with a stranger,
Thou art snared with the words of thy mouth, Thou art taken with the words of thy mouth.
Do this now, my son, and deliver thyself, When thou art come into the hand of thy friend; Go, humble thyself, and make sure thy friend.
Give not sleep to thine eyes, Nor slumber to thine eyelids.
Deliver thyself as a roe from the hand \add of the hunter\add*, And as a bird from the hand of the fowler.
Go to the ant, thou sluggard; Consider her ways, and be wise:
Which having no guide, overseer, or ruler,
Provideth her meat in the summer, \add And\add* gathereth her food in the harvest.
How long wilt thou sleep, O sluggard? When wilt thou arise out of thy sleep?
\add Yet\add* a little sleep, a little slumber, A little folding of the hands to sleep:
So shall thy poverty come as one that travelleth, And thy want as an armed man.
A naughty person, a wicked man, Walketh \add with\add* a froward mouth.
He winketh with his eyes, He speaketh with his feet, He teacheth with his fingers;
Frowardness \add is\add* in his heart, He deviseth mischief continually; He soweth discord.
Therefore shall his calamity come suddenly; Suddenly shall he be broken without remedy.
These six \add things\add* doth the \sc Lord\sc* hate: Yea, seven \add are\add* an abomination unto him:
A proud look, a lying tongue, And hands that shed innocent blood,
A heart that deviseth wicked imaginations, Feet that be swift in running to mischief,
A false witness \add that\add* speaketh lies, And he that soweth discord among brethren.
My son, keep thy father’s commandment, And forsake not the law of thy mother:
Bind them continually upon thine heart, \add And\add* tie them about thy neck.
When thou goest, it shall lead thee; When thou sleepest, it shall keep thee; And \add when\add* thou awakest, it shall talk \add with\add* thee.
For the commandment \add is\add* a lamp; and the law \add is\add* light; And reproofs of instruction \add are\add* the way of life:
To keep thee from the evil woman, From the flattery of the tongue of a strange \add woman\add*.
Lust not after her beauty in thine heart; Neither let her take thee with her eyelids.
For by means of a whorish woman \add a man is brought\add* to a piece of bread: And the adulteress will hunt for the precious life.
Can a man take fire in his bosom, And his clothes not be burnt?
Can one go upon hot coals, And his feet not be burnt?
So he that goeth in to his neighbour’s wife; Whosoever toucheth her shall not be innocent.
\add Men\add* do not despise a thief, if he steal To satisfy his soul when he is hungry;
But \add if\add* he be found, he shall restore sevenfold; He shall give all the substance of his house.
\add But\add* whoso committeth adultery with a woman lacketh understanding: He \add that\add* doeth it destroyeth his own soul.
A wound and dishonour shall he get; And his reproach shall not be wiped away.
For jealousy \add is\add* the rage of a man: Therefore he will not spare in the day of vengeance.
He will not regard any ransom; Neither will he rest content, though thou givest many gifts.
